Topic.Title: Should i dump my puts at the open?

Message.Msg: you are likely to be unpleasantly surprised that your aug $500 puts will not do what you think they wiltl. This is a common problem for those new at options. The implied volatility will be taken out of the option and assuming the stock opens in the $565-569 range will likely open flat from todays close at best. Then as holder's sell to capture what is left of the premium, the stock may bounce and the option really get hit. You may thus find that while you were expecting a nice prpfit, you may find that actually wind up with a loss. You would have been better off to have bought a fewer number of in the money puts.

Message.Title: Consider selling covered calls on part of your shares.
Message.Msg: I have sold the $610 calls three times--for $28, $7, and earlier today for $16. It looks like I will have another opportunity, as the stock price will likely be less than $610 at option expiration in August. After that, assuming the market has not totally cratered, the buzz about the new iphone should carry the stock higher. Definitely expect a recovery at some point in the next two months, if not much sooner. This strategy is best in a tax sheltered account. Also, best when the stock has spiked or there is uncertainty. So, if we are lucky enough to get a bounce, which does seem unlikely, consider selling the Aug $600 calls for a little cash in your account.

Message.Title: Apple To Beat Guidance On Earnings
Message.Msg: old guidance from Q2.... "As we move ahead into the June quarter, I'd like to review our outlook, which includes the types of forward-looking information that Nancy referred to at the beginning of the call. We expect revenue to be about $34 billion compared to $28.6 billion in the June quarter last year. We expect gross margin to be about 41.5%, reflecting approximately $70 million related to stock-based compensation expense. We expect OpEx to be about $3.3 billion, including about $385 million related to stock-based compensation. We expect OI&E to be about $175 million. And we expect the tax rate to be about 25.25%. We are targeting EPS of about $8.68." Good for us

Topic.Title: Here's the reasons why I believe Apple missed

Message.Msg: That's why Apple fan will switch to iPhone 5 this coming fall. Before that, you will see more Galaxy's commercial ads in these few months, why? because they will try to grab more market share while Apple is taking a break. Samsung knows very much the best way to grab the market is to avoid direct competition with Apple, so they have to push out their new product before Apple. The risk to shorten their product development cycle is to compromise their product's quality, this will impact to product's reliability and stability, and that's why we can see more problems happened to Galaxy than to iPhone. For me, the comparison is just like apple and orange. Apple last longer than orange. More fresh orange can be sold during non-apple season. Nevertheless, when it's apple season again, fresh apple will still dominate the market. Do you know there is something called "loyalty" in fashion industry? And, do you notice that which cell phone has higher second hand market value?

Topic.Title: Should i dump my puts at the open?

Message.Msg: I understand and acknowledge what you say about what happened monday, but that is not the case today. Option market makers who price the options always place a large premium of IMPLIED VOLATILITY before a big event like an earnings release for AAPL. They drop this IV sharply after the event takes place and this reduces the premium sharply. Even the options with strike prices close to the money will be affected, but puts like the $500 strike , which are 70 dollars away will be affected much more. Right now the stock is at $572, If it opens here the $500 aug puts will likely open LOWER than where they closed. Watch and see and learn.

Message.Title: Raymond James cuts Apple to outperform 07/25 08:31 AM
Message.Msg: Also NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Piper Jaffray & #$%$ Wednesday said it is reducing its revenue estimate for Apple Inc.'s (AAPL:$600.92,00$-2.91,00-0.48%) fiscal fourth quarter to $34.6 billion from $35.8 billion, as well as lowering its earnings forecast to $8.40 from $9.32 per share after the tech giant reported third-quarter earnings that missed consensus estimates. For the quarter ending September, the research firm also trimmed its iPhone sales estimates by 2 million units to 22 million. In a note, Piper Jaffray senior analyst Gene Munster said that he doesn't expect the iPhone 5 to be released until October. Most analysts had pegged a September launch for the latest version of the popular smartphone. "We believe September could be another quarter where Apple (AAPL:$600.92,00$-2.91,00-0.48%) does not beat its revenue guide by the same magnitude as past quarters," he said

Message.Title: Raymond James lowered to $730 target rates out-perform from a strong buy
Message.Msg: Apple downgraded at Raymond James BY MarketWatch — 9:23 AM ET 07/25/2012 NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Raymond James analysts on Wednesday downgraded their rating on Apple Inc. (AAPL Loading... ) to outperform from strong buy and lowered their price target to $730 from $800 after the tech giant reported fiscal third-quarter results that missed consensus estimates. The company posted revenue of $35 billion and iPhone sales of 26 million, compared to the $35.7 billion in revenue and 28 million in smartphone sales Raymond James had forecast. "While we believe most of the miss is a result of customers delaying their upgrades until the launch of the iPhone 5, which is expected in the fall, flattish trends in Europe are potentially a sign that the iPhone's share gains might become more muted going forward," the analysts said in a note. Shares of Apple (AAPL Loading... ) were down 4.6% in premarket trades.

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: Strong correlation between markets performance and stocks like Apple, Google is well known. Apple disappointed investors, reporting $9.32 in earnings for the quarter ending June 30, 2012, and shares are down sharply after hours. It was not in surprice for me. Last days money outflow from AAPL was noted by I Know First stock forecast system , I am using with good results so far. Yet the latest balance sheet shows the company now has $117.2 billion in cash - an increase of about $7 billion over last quarter and about $41 billion more than in June of 2011. IMO time to buy AAPL on dips for the long term is near. Good Luck!

Message.Title: The Set Up Play - written 6 day ago
Message.Msg: The Set Up Play - This Qtr.By chillbill262003 . 6 days ago . Permalink Verizon will post lackluster Iphone sales tomorrow. While not a pure proxy for Apple sales, it will certainly sting again, in particular given the sell-side's recent numbers coming down on Iphone sales. Next week, Apple reports decent, but not strong results on the anticipation of Iphone 5. This should not be discounted because it is an actual factor that played out ahead of the 4S, which at the time many felt would be the 5. China will help offset a big miss, but the numbers wont be dazzling, in my opinion. Thereafter, the stock will retreat and find some stability near $560-$570. The reason we do not get a bigger wash out is the product cycle on the horizon and the dividend announcement. Dont be surprised if the dividend announcement hits real soon during Apple's weaker stretch of the year. The media will jump all over Apple with typical fear mongering. And here lies the set up play. Come August, near $550 - $575, load the boat. With Iphone 5, Ipad Mini, and a traditionally strong holiday season, we could be ripe for a launch. Couple that with income investors mandated to buy the new dividend yielding stock, and its gravy. $675 by Christmas, $750 by March. 2013 we look to China Mobile and iTV news coming winter and spring. happy investing all.

Message.Title: Macintosh vs Wintel all over again...
Message.Msg: Apple awed the world with candy-coated macintosh computers. Then the big boys got serious about making something consumers could use - the rest is history. The Mac soon became seen as an inferior product, and with a hard locked, closed system - it could not compete against the "Wintel" Juggernaght. Android has exposed AAPL once again as a maker of closed-system inferior products. AAPL was the first out of the gate with the MAC and now the smartphone. They lost the war the first time and will lose it again this time. AAPL's desire to be control freaks have cost them again.

Message.Msg: So are average Chinese and Indians going to sacrifice food and private indoor flush toilets for an Iphone and /or Ipad? Topic.Title: Given the big miss, shouldn't AAPL have warned about the quater?

Message.Msg: Why should they? It's not hard to come up with the amount of smart devices that Apple would have had to sell to maintain momentum quarter after quarter after quarter. Conservatively, Apple cannot sustain consistent growth forever. By my numbers, since the introduction of the first Apple smartphone, and just the smart phone alone, Apple would have had to have to sustain a 30M unit over the previous quarter, quarter after quarter. From the inception of their smartphone, Apple should have sold in this last quarter approximately 80M smartphone on a sustain 15% growth quarter after quarter since the inception of the smartphone. They didnt. Thats why China is having problems, they cannot sustain double digit growth quarter after quarter after quarter, or even year after year, the numbers say sustainable growth cannot be maintained. Although the GDP of the US is very lack luster, being able to sustain GDP growth in the 1.5% to 2.0% is realistic to move the economy forward, but it will take years to recover. Apple has had some blow out quarters but Apple should have tempered that with something more realistic about growth. Identifying a sustainable growth number to target and hit, anything above that is a positive surprise. And the bigger something gets, at some point, even to hit conservative growth targets may just be difficult to achieve due to the sheer volume in the numbers that make up that growth. Having some huge numbers, thats just fodder for the competition to go after, and at some point, the competition with surpass you, and likewise, the competition at some point will experience the same growth problems where they are not realistic. At this point, Samsung cannot maintain the growth, the numbers for growth projections say otherwise.

Message.Title: Perspective is Everything
Message.Msg: BAMACHICA'S TOP 10 REASONS YOU SHOULD BE BULLISH ON AAPL: 1) Overall, AAPL has done nothing but GROW over the past 30+ years---A LOT! 2) All stocks go UP and all stocks go DOWN at some point---sometimes aggressively, but if you adhere to the simplistic adage "Buy low, sell high" you can't go wrong---ever 3) Growth money isn't really YOUR money unless you sell and hold it as cash---therefore, you accept #1 and #2 4) Greedy = Losing Money at some point when investing in the market 5) AAPL is a strong company with great leadership, quality products, and a sound pipeline. How many of you have a computer you bought 12 years ago that runs as fast and as efficiently as the day you bought it?? I do and it's a Mac! Its's been passed down to each of my 5 children and is now on child #5. How many Microsoft products can make that claim? NONE! Note that this Mac is being used by kids, so that alone is amazing! 6) Even though Tim Cook is an Auburn alum (ROLL TIDE!) he has stepped in and is carrying on Job's legacy quite well. How many of you could step in Job's shoes and continue to revolutionize the IT world? 7) My "financial advisor" advised me in March 2009 (after the October 2008 crash) NOT to invest in AAPL. It was at roughly $82/share. 4 years---and it's around $600/share. My rationale for buying at the time? It was at an all time low, AAPL stores opening everywhere and the products speak for themselves. Everywhere I look there is someone, ages 6-96-with some type of AAPL product. He advised me it wasn't a good time to buy. HAHAHAHA 8) Moral of #7---great product, solid company, buy on drops. You WILL have a great ROI 9) Second Moral of #7---sometimes you can over analyze stuff. Case in point---I can touch a patient's feet and tell you if they are in shock and have poor blood flow. I can also get dopplers, scans, and fancy tests. But nothing beats good old fashioned common sense. AAPL will grow, common sense 10) True AAPL devotees are not going to go buy a new phone right now, they are waiting for the new thing! Sales are down, yet they are outselling every other company in the world. Its summer dude---parents and kids are spending money on vacations, not luxuries or upgrades right now. Use your common sense sense---I am buying a Macbook for my 4th child next week for her first year in college. I didn't buy it in June cause she doesn't need it till August and we had vacation to pay for. Yes, all my kids get a Mac upon high school graduation and entering college. Wish I had been one of my kids lol! All my rambling is to say---we are spending money on going to the beach, or Six Flags, or our cabin in Mentone, or going to a Braves game.....it's summer dude, calm down, I will spend money on AAPL products in August for school and in Nov/Dec for Christmas!

Message.Title: TOP 10 REASONS TO BUY AAPL NOW!
Message.Msg: BAMACHICA'S TOP 10 REASONS YOU SHOULD BE BULLISH ON AAPL: 1) Overall, AAPL has done nothing but GROW over the past 30+ years---A LOT! 2) All stocks go UP and all stocks go DOWN at some point---sometimes aggressively, but if you adhere to the simplistic adage "Buy low, sell high" you can't go wrong---ever 3) Growth money isn't really YOUR money unless you sell and hold it as cash---therefore, you accept #1 and #2 4) Greedy = Losing Money at some point when investing in the market 5) AAPL is a strong company with great leadership, quality products, and a sound pipeline. How many of you have a computer you bought 12 years ago that runs as fast and as efficiently as the day you bought it?? I do and it's a Mac! Its's been passed down to each of my 5 children and is now on child #5. How many Microsoft products can make that claim? NONE! Note that this Mac is being used by kids, so that alone is amazing! 6) Even though Tim Cook is an Auburn alum (ROLL TIDE!) he has stepped in and is carrying on Job's legacy quite well. How many of you could step in Job's shoes and continue to revolutionize the IT world? 7) My "financial advisor" advised me in March 2009 (after the October 2008 crash) NOT to invest in AAPL. It was at roughly $82/share. 4 years---and it's around $600/share. My rationale for buying at the time? It was at an all time low, AAPL stores opening everywhere and the products speak for themselves. Everywhere I look there is someone, ages 6-96-with some type of AAPL product. He advised me it wasn't a good time to buy. HAHAHAHA 8) Moral of #7---great product, solid company, buy on drops. You WILL have a great ROI 9) Second Moral of #7---sometimes you can over analyze stuff. Case in point---I can touch a patient's feet and tell you if they are in shock and have poor blood flow. I can also get dopplers, scans, and fancy tests. But nothing beats good old fashioned common sense. AAPL will grow, common sense 10) True AAPL devotees are not going to go buy a new phone right now, they are waiting for the new thing! Sales are down, yet they are outselling every other company in the world. Its summer dude---parents and kids are spending money on vacations, not luxuries or upgrades right now. Use your common sense sense---I am buying a Macbook for my 4th child next week for her first year in college. I didn't buy it in June cause she doesn't need it till August and we had vacation to pay for. Yes, all my kids get a Mac upon high school graduation and entering college. Wish I had been one of my kids lol! All my rambling is to say---we are spending money on going to the beach, or Six Flags, or our cabin in Mentone, or going to a Braves game.....it's summer dude, calm down, I will spend money on AAPL products in August for school and in Nov/Dec for Christmas

Message.Title: Expectations & Reality
Message.Msg: Few truths with this quarter's results. First, we have seen some slow down, in particular in markets like Europe who are hurting right now economically. Second, we definitely are feeling the Iphone 5 affect. If you are going to buy one now, you are going to wait. No doubt about it. That certainly affected return customers in addition to people like myself ready to chuck out my BB for an Iphone 5. With all this said, the company easily exceeded its guidance from last quarter. Unfortunately though, this company lives in a rare air where the sell-side cannot get a grasp on reality. The sell-side, for the most part, missed bad this quarter. Few key expectations being Raymond James, Bernstein, etc. The good news is expectations will be realistic next quarter, on low guidance and the sell-side finally following suit with realistic numbers. And then.... we get our catalysts. Looking at fundamentals, this stock is attractive right now, at 12x forward earnings. It grows more attractive each time it falls. I think with a good tape in August, we bottom at $550ish. On a bad tape, we fall to $525. But don't confuse my words here, I am a big bull for the second half of 2012 and first quarter of 2013. Some other factors that can help? 1.) QE3... if the markets get all caught up with more stimulus in early August (Fed meeting Aug. 1), we honestly will put this quarter behind us rather fast. 2.) dividend..... income investors need to add this to their portfolios ahead of x-dividend date in early August. Don't underestimate the purchasing power here. Top institutions with dividend portfolios will be mandated to jump on this stock. 3.) any push up on the Iphone 5 to September will be huge. The concerns.... subsidies, delay in Iphone 5, and a major economic slowdown

Message.Msg: Forget about the fundamentals. If the fundamentals turn the stock around, it will show up in the chart. Message.Title: Iphone 5 - The ecosystem
Message.Msg: Yes, there are some really nice products on the market, that on face value, simply speaking of hardware, are comparable or even a little ahead of the last iterations of iphone. But, when Apple meets or beats that hardware expectation, there is also a huge software component that everyone is forgetting. Iphone 5 will have the ecosystem behind it. No one else has that. Itunes? Really? When are you ever leaving Itunes folks. Google, Microsoft, etc have tried long and hard to penetrate that platform to zero success. Iphone 5 will marriage a perfect mix of hardware and software, into an experience that no other company can execute. Iphone, Ipad, Itunes, Ipod, and later Itv. I personally am betting on big things from this ecosystem. Everyone needs to stop about bigger screens from competitors. Ridiculous

Message.Title: $1130 Gabelli target on AAPL
Message.Msg: Gabelli on Apple (AAPL): Shares Could Skyrocket Once Focus Turns To Earnings Power, Not Product Cyclicality 12:00 PM ET, 07/25/2012 - Street Insider Gabelli maintains a 'Buy' on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL). Gabelli analyst, said, "We prefer focusing on Apple s increasingly bigger earning power rather than product cyclicality. Based on highest quarterly shipment profile and our near-term shipment growth estimates, we believe Apple s supply chain has the capacity to generate $45 billion of quarterly revenue in FY 2013...We view weakness in AAPL shares due to the cyclical nature of its product transition as buying opportunity." Gabelli's analysis is that AAPL shares are currently trading at 5.9x and 13.0x FY 13 EBITDA and EPS estimates of $76.3 billion and $57, respectively (at a share price of $600. Going forward, for 2013, based on 14x forward P/E plus cash, at PMV of around $1,130. We calculate a 2013 PMV of $1,130 based on our 14x forward P/E plus cash."

Message.Title: AAPL miss is a huge buying opportunity read
Message.Msg: “Apple (AAPL) surprised investors last night by missing earnings for the quarter just past and providing guidance for the current quarter that is well below analyst estimates. Apple blamed the global economy for some of the miss but also said expectations for a new iPhone5 were hindering sales of the current model,” Jeff Macke reports for Yahoo Finance. “‘This is a company that likes to create a buzz,’ says Todd Schoenberger, managing principal of The BlackBay Group. ‘Unfortunately that probably backfired on them right now because every is waiting for these sensational products but they don’t have a delivery date,’” Macke reports. “Schoenberger ticks through his other concerns. Domestic sales have been soft for two straight quarters, emerging markets are soft, and Apple’s (alleged) move into smaller iPads is an atypical effort to follow competitors into a market. No doubt these headwinds have him cautious about the stock, right?” Macke reports, “No way! ‘I would go long now and I’d put leverage on it,’ he all but shouts in the attached video. ‘Buy it now, $800 in one year. Hold me to it!’”

Topic.Title: aea how come aapl ticking ups?!

Message.Msg: Compared to the year-ago quarter, Apple's industry-leading gross margins expanded by 2.6% (from 41.7% to 42.8%), giving it more profit from each unit sold Compared to the year-ago quarter, iPhone unit sales grew 28% to 26 million units (since the iPhone is the best iPod Apple ever made, the iPod unit "decline" by 10% to 6.8 million units represents net upselling to costlier products rather than net losses of sales) Apple sold 17 million iPad units, 84% more units than in the year-ago quarter Despite flat PC sales globally, and US sales of PCs down over 5%, Macs grew 2% year-over-year to 4 million units in the quarter (its US share grew to 12%, but its single-digit global PC share hasn't reached the top 5 vendors) Profit grew 19.6% year-over-year from $7.79/sh to $9.32/sh, and a $10 billion share repurchase program promises to counter stock-compensation dilution and a dividend of $2.65/sh will be paid on 8/16 to holders of record on 8/13.

Message.Title: Why we are ...gulp ...shorting $AAPL
Message.Msg: After liquidating our small long position, we just initiated a small short position in $AAPL today at $578. Raving of red flag in front of $AAPL bulls, our thesis is simple: 1) Everyone and their mother is already in $AAPL. 2) The earnings miss, and expected 2nd miss next qtr. 3) Everyone looking and praying for an October iPhone 5. 4) But $QCOM chip yields will gate the success of the launch and/or might even cause a delay beyond October. 5) Also $AAPL is holding a boat load of cash, but yields on cash is sinking. 6) QE3 on tap, will also cause a fall in the value of the dollar 7) Expecting $AAPL to make some more M&A moves. So we are using the funds from shorting $AAPL to buy other non tech blue chips that pay 2x dividends and have lower P/E rates, but similar PEGs. But not this is not a long term short... more a tactical short which we expect to trade around over the next qtr.

Topic.Title: Apple Options scam?

Message.Msg: Typically, option prices only carry a time component, so they behave as you apparently expect. That is, if the (out-of-the-money) share price heads dramatically toward the strike price in just one night, with some more time to go before expiration, then you expect the premium to go up. But when there are upcoming catalysts (such as earnings reports) that are going to materialize before the expiration date, the premium carries a large component that represents increased potential for movement. When that event passes, if the hoped-for move does not occur, you are left with only time premium (which can be small if the exp date is close). Worse, AAPL earnings reports are typically met with knee jerk reactions that cause emphasized moves in whichever direction, and subsequent days can see a reversal in share price (which in this case would further harm your chances of reaching $570). In other words, yesterday you paid through the nose for the potential of the event to bring you to $570. Virtually no time premium to speak of. Mostly event premium. The event failed you, and you are left with only time (and very little of that). Lesson: you pay dearly for options before scheduled events. If it doesn't move as far as you want, it's gone, especially on weeklies. Does this make sense to you? If not, then I recommend staying away from weekly options. Thompson

Options are tough as is, weeklies are brutal particularly around earnings. Good Luck.
